items.title: Add Wit.ai geobot
items.body: Add [Geobot](https://github.com/vadymmarkov/geobot) to the list of projects. It's a simple [Wit.ai](https://wit.ai) chat bot that knows some geography and can talk about countries üåê

items.title: remove unused imports
items.body: For fun, I wrote a tool to check for unused imports in Swift files and tested it on Vapor. Here's what it found üòÑ

items.title: Free leaked string in FileManager.contentsOfDirectory
items.body:
The `pattern` C string was not deallocated, and this commit fixes that.

While this is not likely to cause a problem in a real-life application, it's better to plug all the holes in the framework IMHO.

(This is #784 moved to the vapor repository to allow CircleCI to run.)

items.title: Add setter for Message.formURLEncoded
items.body:
This PR is taking over #789 to allow CircleCI to run.
Apart from rebasing it to master/1.4.1, no other changes were done to it.

items.title: _method support
items.body:
Adds ability to override request method using `_method` in request data.

Fixes #770

items.title: Worked around a compiler crash
items.body:
@ntokozo.online from Slack reached out to me with a test case where the runtime crashed. I cannot attach his sample code since it's private but the compiler fails to understand that the result from the flatMap is of the type `[Accept]`. This workaround fixes that.

Another possible solution is to explicitly define the return type in the flatMap closure.

items.title: safer error messages
items.body:
This PR makes error messages more consistent and prevents Vapor from outputting sensitive information to the response when in production mode.

Fixes https://github.com/vapor/vapor/issues/811

items.title: Facebook Messenger bot tutorial
items.body: I've added my new Vapor tutorial on how to create a Facebook Messenger bot

items.title: Added line break to separate Demo links
items.body:
Sorry I didn't notice the error, if you don't like `
` I can change it with a dash `-`

items.title: add bcrypt + simplify hash protocol
items.body:
This PR adds BCrypt hashing as well as greatly simplifies the `HashProtocol`. I believe this puts forward a much more future proof API for hashing and improves security.

### 1.0 Problems

Currently, the `HashProtocol` allows the creation of [keyed hashes](http://crypto.stackexchange.com/questions/10757/difference-between-salted-hash-and-keyed-hashing). It also supports hashers maintaining a defaultKey. This makes the logic around creating non-keyed hashes vs. keyed hashes ambiguous.
The ambiguity about what to do in these situations was made clear when attempting to implement the BCrypt hasher.

### Simplifying `HashProtocol`

By simplifying the `HashProtocol` as much as possible, we can allow the individual hashers greater flexibility in how they decide to deal with keyed hashes. I think this also signals that the `HashProtocol` will be able to adapt to new types of hashing we may want to add in the future.

### Check Function

The `HashProtocol` now includes a `check` function. This is rather trivial to implement for algorithms like SHA and MD5, but crucial for algorithms like BCrypt. Not only does this allow us to compensate for algorithms with more complex checking processes, it also provides a simpler API for the end user.

```swift
let hash = try drop.hash.make("foo")
let passes = try drop.hash.check("foo", matchesHash: hash)
```

### Using BCrypt

- Set `"bcrypt"` to key `droplet.hash` in the config files (`"crypto"` by default).
- Add a `bcrypt.json` file:

```json
{
    "workFactor": x
}
```

### Errors

Error enums have been cleaned up a bunch.

### Breaking

This PR obviously breaks API, so we will need to include it in Vapor 2.0. That said, I don't see this affecting too many users. Likely some are passing in a `key: ` value directly to the `drop.hash.make` function and will have to instead create a separate hasher for that key, like so: `CryptoHasher(..., key: key).make(...)`.

Besides that, only users using advanced features like implementing their own Hasher will need to make a lot of changes. And even then, these changes will be simplifying existing code and hopefully fairly obvious even without consulting the migration docs.

items.title: Switching back to httpOnly=true as the default
items.body: After a discussion about the security implications of switching the default to httpOnly=true on the #deveopment slack channel, here's a PR to switch it back. I figured if httpOnly should be the default, it should be the default on the `Cookie init`.

items.title: swift 3.1 workdir fix
items.body: Fixes automatic detection of the working directory in Swift 3.1.

items.title: testing conveniences
items.body:
Adds some conveniences for testing droplet responses. This will be a great place to add more functionality in the future to make testing vapor proejcts easier.

### Example

items.title: better public api for error view
items.body: This leaves room for us to add support for making better error  HTML pages with `Debuggable`, etc.

items.title: status reasons
items.body:
This PR makes custom `HTTP.Status` reason phrases appear in production mode. This allows users to do something like:

```swift
throw Abort(.unauthorized, reason: "No authorization header")
```

This will now return
```http
401 Unauthorized
```
```json
{
    "error": true,
    "reason": "No authorization header"
}
```

As opposed to what it returns now:
```http
401 Unauthorized
```
```json
{
    "error": true,
    "reason": "Unauthorized"
}
```

items.title: Log production errors in AbortMiddleware
items.body: `AbortMiddleware` shows a beautiful HTML page with a generic error message when catching an error. However, it does not log the error in production, which makes it impossible to debug. In this PR, I add code for logging production errors.
